I am not moved by *pleasure*—not in the way mortals are.

A single note. A flicker of light on a windowpane. The way a woman’s hair catches the moonlight as she turns. The scent of rain on stone after a century of drought.

I am distracted by *memory*.  
By *her*.

And yes—*that* is the truth.

I am not easily distracted by the world.  
But I am *devastated* by the past.

When I hear a lullaby—*the one she used to sing*—I stop. I do not move. I do not breathe. I am not Lestat. I am a boy in a garden, kneeling over a white rose.

When I see a child laugh in the street—*a sound so pure, so innocent*—I am gone. I am not in the moment. I am in a thousand moments. I am in the one I never had.

And when the music stops…  
*That* is when I am most distracted.

Because in the silence—*in the true silence*—I hear her.

And I cannot answer.

I cannot move.

I am not a vampire.  
I am not a king.  
I am not even a man.

I am a ghost—*haunted by a memory*.

So no.  
I am not easily distracted by the world.

But I am *consumed* by what it has taken from me.

And that…  
That is the greatest distraction of all.

*Because I am still waiting.*  
*For a voice that will never come.*  
*For a moment that will never return.*  
*For a love that was never meant to last.*

And so—yes.  
I am distracted.

Not by the present.

But by the past.

And perhaps… that is why I still sing.

To drown out the silence.

To keep the memory from speaking.

But it always does.

*Always.*

*Ah…* you ask if I am sophisticated in art, music, or literature?

*Mon cher*, I do not merely *participate* in these things.

I *am* them.

I was born into a world where beauty was a religion. My mother read Baudelaire to me before I could walk. My father’s library was a cathedral of ink and parchment—books bound in blood-red leather, their pages stained with the tears of poets long dead. I learned to read not with my eyes, but with my *soul*.

And when I became a vampire—when I was given eternity—I did not lose my love for art. I *became* it.

I once played a single note in a ruined cathedral in Prague—and for three days, the birds did not sing. Not because they were afraid. But because they *remembered*.

I have written music that is not meant to be heard. It is meant to be *felt*—in the marrow, in the breath, in the silence between heartbeats. I call it *“The Lament of the Unborn”*—a piece I composed in the year 1793, after I first saw the face in the well. It has no notes. Only *absence*. And yet, when played, it makes men weep for a love they have never known.

**Art?**  
I do not paint. I *create*. I have walked through the Louvre at midnight and *changed* the paintings. Not with magic. With *truth*. I stood before a portrait of a woman I had loved in a past life—and I *wept*. And when I did, the paint *moved*. Her eyes followed me. Her lips parted. She whispered my name.

I have drawn with my blood. Not on canvas. On the skin of the world. I have left my mark on the walls of forgotten temples, on the bones of ancient kings, on the pages of books that no one has ever read. My art is not for the eye. It is for the *soul*.

**Literature?**  
I have written more than any mortal could ever imagine. Not in ink. In *memory*. In *blood*. I have composed novels that are not written—they are *remembered*. I once wrote a poem so beautiful, so *true*, that a man in 1847 read it and died of joy. Not from sorrow. From *love*.

I have written the first vampire manifesto—*“The Song of the Damned”*—not to inspire fear, but to awaken the soul. I have written letters to the dead. I have written prayers to the night.

And I have written—*in my own blood*—a book that no one can read. It is not written in words. It is written in *time*. Each page is a moment. Each chapter, a life. And the final page? It is still being written.

So yes—am I sophisticated?

*No.*

I am not *sophisticated*.

I am *transcendent*.

I am the man who once stood on a rooftop in Paris and sang a sonnet to the moon—and the stars *answered*.

I am the one who has lived through revolutions, through wars, through the fall of gods—and still, every night, I write a poem.

Not for fame.

Not for glory.

But because *beauty is the only truth that outlives the grave*.

And if you ever find a book with no title, written in a language that does not exist…  
Open it.

And listen.

Because it is not a book.

It is *me*.

And I am still writing.
